subject: History
note: Content vehicles for KS3 History. Seeded from Topics layer + v4 teacher feedback (Adeyemi).

vehicles.name: Medieval Britain 1066-1509
vehicles.description: Development of Church, state and society in Medieval Britain — from the Norman Conquest through Magna Carta, the Black Death, and the Wars of the Roses.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils construct an argument about whether power shifted from the monarch to the people between 1066 and 1509? Can they evaluate the significance of Magna Carta using contemporary and modern perspectives? Can they analyse primary sources critically, considering provenance and purpose?
success_criteria: Construct a sustained argument about change in power 1066-1509
Evaluate the significance of Magna Carta with evidence
Analyse a medieval source considering its provenance and purpose
Explain how the Black Death caused social and economic change

vehicles.name: The Elizabethan Age
vehicles.description: England under Elizabeth I — religious settlement, exploration, the Spanish Armada, and the development of English national identity.
key_events: Execution of Mary Queen of Scots 1587
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils construct an argument about whether Elizabeth's reign was truly a 'Golden Age'? Can they analyse the Armada Portrait as propaganda? Can they evaluate the impact of English exploration from multiple perspectives, including colonised peoples?
success_criteria: Evaluate whether Elizabeth's reign was a 'Golden Age' with evidence for and against
Analyse the Armada Portrait as a piece of propaganda
Explain the religious settlement and its consequences
Consider the impact of exploration from multiple perspectives

vehicles.name: Ideas, Power, Industry and Empire 1745-1901
vehicles.description: The transformation of Britain through industrialisation, the expansion of empire, and the growth of democratic ideas — from Enlightenment to Victorian era.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils construct an argument about who benefited and who suffered from industrialisation and empire? Can they critically analyse sources about working conditions, considering purpose and reliability? Can they evaluate the consequences of empire from multiple perspectives?
success_criteria: Explain causes and consequences of the Industrial Revolution
Construct an argument about the impact of empire using multiple perspectives
Analyse industrial-era sources critically (provenance, purpose, reliability)
Evaluate the significance of abolition and reform movements

vehicles.name: Challenges 1901 to Present Day
vehicles.description: Challenges for Britain, Europe and the wider world in the 20th and 21st centuries — World Wars, decolonisation, social change, and globalisation.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils construct sustained arguments about the causes and consequences of 20th century conflicts? Can they evaluate the reliability of propaganda as a historical source? Can they analyse multiple perspectives on decolonisation?
success_criteria: Construct a causal argument about a 20th century conflict
Evaluate propaganda sources critically
Analyse decolonisation from multiple perspectives
Explain the significance of social change in 20th century Britain

vehicles.name: The Holocaust
vehicles.description: Understanding the Holocaust — antisemitism, Nazi persecution, genocide, resistance, and the legacy of remembrance.
vehicles.assessment_guidance: Can pupils explain the escalation from discrimination to genocide? Can they use testimony sensitively as historical evidence? Can they construct an argument about the importance of remembrance? This topic requires particular sensitivity — follow school and UCL Centre for Holocaust Education guidance.
success_criteria: Explain the stages of persecution from discrimination to genocide
Use Holocaust testimony as historical evidence with sensitivity
Construct an argument about why the Holocaust matters today
Analyse different responses to the Holocaust (resistance, rescue, bystanding)
